awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Cyber-Physical Situational Awareness for the Power Grid Infrastructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Worldwide initiatives to modernize the electricity delivery systems, at both the bulk interconnection and local community scales, promise increased reliability, efficiency, and sustainability through the use of advanced information (cyber) and electrical energy (physical) infrastructure. The power grid's increasing dependence on information systems and technologies however challenges its capability to become aware of and accordingly recover from unexpected incidents.  This is because the traditional situational awareness paradigm in grid operations has so far limited to events and contingencies at the physical grid layer. A vivid example of this limitation is the recent cyber-attacks to the Ukrainian power grid, where cyber intrusions invisible to grid operators caused unauthorized tripping of circuit breakers and thereby wide-area blackouts. To address this status quo, the objective of this CAREER project is to equip grid operators with better tools to monitor the underlying cyber-states, particularly focusing on the operational quality and security of the cyber layer. Its successful completion will transform the grid operational paradigm by providing integrated situational awareness capabilities of both cyber and physical assets, towards more efficient, secure, and resilient power gird infrastructures.  

The overarching goal of this CAREER project is to develop a suite of improved situational awareness tools that can seamlessly bridge the cyber-physical layers of today's electricity delivery infrastructures. At the bulk transmission level, we propose to revitalize the design of traditional energy control center systems, in particular the topology processing and security analysis modules, to jointly infer the cyber-physical operating states and to efficiently evaluate the security impacts of potential cyber-physical contingencies. As for small-footprint microgrids, we propose to investigate the flexibility and vulnerability trade-offs between centralized and distributed architectures in the presence of cyber-intrusions to communication links. Our research plan consists of three cohesive thrusts: T1) Optimal topology inference and cyber state estimation using a multitude of cyber-physical data; T2) Real-time cyber-physical dynamic security assessment by developing the 'cyber-contingency distribution factors' and model-free stability analysis methods; and T3) Distributed microgrid operations under cyber-physical disturbances and countermeasure designs. This CAREER development plan will also integrate an education plan with  the research goals by i) developing a learning platform with cyber-physical grid visualization that is appropriate for pre-college students, ii) introducing course projects and special topics on the cyber aspects to college-level power engineering curricula, and iii) promoting undergraduate research experience especially for female and under-represented engineering students.

por.por_cntn:
Increasing effort in deepening the decarbonization and electrification of various industry sectors is currently pursued to tackle the climate challenge, making transformative changes to the energy sector.  The centerpiece for this transition is perhaps the electricity infrastructure, or the power grid. Rapid electrification and uptake of renewable resources of energy are expected to process as much as 80% of electricity worldwide by 2030. The implied transition is nothing short of a paradigm shift for all facets of power grid analysis and operations. For example, the integration of renewable generations not only introduces uncertainty in daily operations, but also amplifies the negative impacts of extreme weather events. Meanwhile, the power system’s growing reliance on the information systems and cyber technologies makes it more vulnerable to natural or man-made anomalies, as demonstrated by recent cyber attacks on the critical energy infrastructure. This CAREER project is exactly motivated by the energy transition into a sustainable, secure, and resilient infrastructure.

The main results of this CAREER project include a suite of monitoring and decision-making tools for efficient and resilient power grid operations, by leveraging the advances in machine learning (ML) and optimization. Our algorithmic design has neatly utilized the domain knowledge of physical power system models to provide the analytical guarantees and provably efficiency for the resultant operational solutions. We have provided three lines of research results. First, we have revitalized the network-level modeling of grid topology changes like bus splits, a type of events of increasing concern due to their connection to the cyber layer. We have developed a concise model for the traditional node-breaker representation, that allows for real-time monitoring and optimization of bus-split topology changes. Second, we have designed the neural network (NN) based power flow predictive models to attain fast adaptation and scalable implementation. By incorporating the network connectivity, we have used graph-based NN for predicting real-time dispatch that can easily adapt to varying grid topology, as well as for empowering decentralized resources to pursue optimal emergency responses against extreme contingencies. Third, we have put forth a fully data-driven framework for modeling the power system dynamics and further using it for locating external disturbances. By connecting to oscillation networks, our approach recognizes the analytical equivalence between pair-wise cross-correlation of ambient signals and the input-output responses in grid dynamics and utilizes these recovered responses to locate the input source of oscillations. Our algorithmic solutions have been successfully validated in a realistic operational environment using real-world test systems.

Broader Impacts: Results from this project have contributed to the ongoing energy transition by addressing the external uncertainty and vulnerability. They have been shared with academia, national labs, and industry partners through presentations and research collaborations. These dissemination efforts have led to real-world impact in increasing the sustainability and resilience of power grid infrastructure, as well as shed light on the design of general cyber-physical systems. The research results have also been integrated into the PI's education and outreach activities including teaching, mentoring, and broadening participation in STEM.
